title: Forces, Motion, and Friction

vocab.definition: A push or pull that can change how an object moves
The act of moving from one place to another
A force that slows down or stops moving objects
The force that pulls objects toward Earth
A type of friction from air that slows moving objects
A graph that shows how distance changes over time to describe motion
Forces that are equal in size and opposite in direction; they do not change motion
Forces that are not equal; they cause a change in motion (speed up, slow down, or change direction)
A non-contact force that can push or pull certain metals and magnets
Friction that helps tires or shoes grip a surface so you do not slip
Which way an object moves (like forward, left, up)
How much matter is in an object
How an object's speed or direction changes
The overall push or pull when all forces are combined
A substance like oil or grease that reduces friction
A force that happens when objects touch (like friction or a push)
The flat surface you stand or move on; often used when describing friction examples

teachingNotes: Use hands-on activities to demonstrate different forces. Have students push and pull objects on different surfaces to experience friction. Drop objects to show gravity's effect.
